Patch Set 37:

I've squashed the first 8 patchsets into one, given that they represent kind of the minimum functionality for CertificateService, uploading a cert, and reloading bmcweb.  Hopefully this will make the series a lot easier to review and test, as we can test the full flow, not just one small piece at a time.

Commit message still needs cleaned up, as I just concatenated the whole thing.  I can do that if you want.

If you really want to check this in as 8 patchsets for a good reason, we can chat, but i think this approach is going to get your patchsets into master faster.

(2 comments)

Patch Set 38:

(1 comment)

In this whole series, I don't see a path forward for users with an existing HTTPS key, as you've moved the location, now users will have an extra key file lying around, and their systems will be changing their serial, and TLS pinning.

Was this your intent, or is that something you're planning on cleaning up?

Patch Set 39:

> Patch Set 38:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> When I check this out, I'm seeing it 500 error on my system
> 
> Is there another patchset I need in series with this one?  Are there certificate components that aren't enabled for the whole build, and only enabled for IBM?
> 
> GET https://10.243.49.9/redfish/v1/CertificateService/CertificateLocations
> 
> {
>     "@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#CertificateLocations.CertificateLocations",
>     "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/CertificateService/CertificateLocations",
>     "@odata.type": "#CertificateLocations.v1_0_0.CertificateLocations",
>     "Description": "Defines a resource that an administrator can use in order tolocate all certificates installed on a given service",
>     "Id": "CertificateLocations",
>     "Links": {
>         "Certificates": []
>     },
>     "Name": "Certificate Locations",
>     "error": {
>         "@Message.ExtendedInfo": [
>             {
>                 "@odata.type": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#Message.v1_0_0.Message",
>                 "Message": "The request failed due to an internal service error.  The service is still operational.",
>                 "MessageArgs": [],
>                 "MessageId": "Base.1.4.0.InternalError",
>                 "Resolution": "Resubmit the request.  If the problem persists, consider resetting the service.",
>                 "Severity": "Critical"
>             }
>         ],
>         "code": "Base.1.4.0.InternalError",
>         "message": "The request failed due to an internal service error.  The service is still operational."
>     }
> }
two of the certificate services are part of only meta-ibm not sure if these need to be added to intel specific repo or moved to generic repo.
probably certificate locations need a fix, pick certificates only from available certificate services.

./meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/image/obmc-phosphor-image.bbappend:    phosphor-nslcd-cert-config \
./meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/image/obmc-phosphor-image.bbappend:    phosphor-nslcd-authority-cert-config \

(2 comments)

Will check and decide if ldap and authority should be moved to generic meta-phosphor layer.
at present https is in meta-phosphor layer so getLocations should not fail

./meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/image/obmc-phosphor-image.bbappend:    phosphor-nslcd-cert-config \
./meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/image/obmc-phosphor-image.bbappend:    phosphor-nslcd-authority-cert-config \
./meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/images/obmc-phosphor-image.bb:    phosphor-bmcweb-cert-config \

Please check if phosphor-certificate-manager instance is running
 1830 root      8720 S    phosphor-certificate-manager --endpoint=https --path

Patch Set 40:

This patch from phoshor-certificate-manager is required to test HTTPS certificates, there was an issue fixed related to parsing of Subject in the certificate.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-certificate-manager/+/22479

Patch Set 41:

> If this is to be checked in, those need to be submitted to meta-phosphor, as you're attempting to enable certificate service for everyone, not just IBM.

Hi Ed - what is your preference?  This is enabled for everyone or we wrap the certificate service code in bmcweb in a #define that is turned off by default?  Or something else?

Patch Set 41:

> Patch Set 41:
> 
> > If this is to be checked in, those need to be submitted to meta-phosphor, as you're attempting to enable certificate service for everyone, not just IBM.
> 
> Hi Ed - what is your preference?  This is enabled for everyone or we wrap the certificate service code in bmcweb in a #define that is turned off by default?  Or something else?

My preference would be to enable it for everyone.  At the end of the day, replacing an https cert is really a webserver feature, and it doesn't make a lot of sense for someone to disable it, given that if you don't use it, it doesn't hurt you.

Patch Set 41:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 41:

(5 comments)

> Patch Set 40:
> 
> > Patch Set 40:
> > 
> > This patch from phoshor-certificate-manager is required to test HTTPS certificates, there was an issue fixed related to parsing of Subject in the certificate.
> > 
> > https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-certificate-manager/+/22479
> 
> Will attempt with this patch today.

I checked this patch out, and manually added phosphor-certificate-manager to my build (it's not included by default)?
Still seeing an internal service error.  Any other ideas?  I'm going to enable and dump logging shortly.

{
    "@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#CertificateLocations.CertificateLocations",
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/CertificateService/CertificateLocations",
    "@odata.type": "#CertificateLocations.v1_0_0.CertificateLocations",
    "Description": "Defines a resource that an administrator can use in order tolocate all certificates installed on a given service",
    "Id": "CertificateLocations",
    "Links": {
        "Certificates": []
    },
    "Name": "Certificate Locations",
    "error": {

            {
                "@odata.type": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#Message.v1_0_0.Message",
                "Message": "The request failed due to an internal service error.  The service is still operational.",
                "MessageArgs": [],
                "MessageId": "Base.1.4.0.InternalError",
                "Resolution": "Resubmit the request.  If the problem persists, consider resetting the service.",
                "Severity": "Critical"
            }
        ],
        "code": "Base.1.4.0.InternalError",
        "message": "The request failed due to an internal service error.  The service is still operational."
    }

Patch Set 41:

Hold the phones.  Looks like phosphor-bmcweb-cert-config got added in a slightly odd way, and I wasn't pulling it in even though I thought I was.

We should probably be adding phosphor-bmcweb-cert-config at the same time we add bmcweb, to avoid the possibility of getting one but not the other.

On the other hand.... maybe we should add the cert config in the bmcweb recipe itself?

I'll submit a patch so people don't hit the same issue I did.

Retesting now.

Patch Set 41:

> Patch Set 41:
> 
> Hold the phones.  Looks like phosphor-bmcweb-cert-config got added in a slightly odd way, and I wasn't pulling it in even though I thought I was.
> 
> We should probably be adding phosphor-bmcweb-cert-config at the same time we add bmcweb, to avoid the possibility of getting one but not the other.
> 
> On the other hand.... maybe we should add the cert config in the bmcweb recipe itself?
> 
> I'll submit a patch so people don't hit the same issue I did.
> 
> Retesting now.


Tests I ran:
Pulled down the redfish GET interfaces, they appear to be correct.
Grabbed the default certificate string, loaded it into openssl and compared to the old one.  It looks the same (with the exception of the serial numbers and actual keys, which is expected)
Ran redfish service validator.  No failures on CertificateService.

Ran a POST to update a certificate:
generated a certificate with:
openssl req -newkey rsa:2048 -nodes -keyout domain.key -x509 -days 365 -out domain.crt
cat domain.key > domain
cat domain.crt >> domain

Then from python write a quick script to do the upload:
import requests
with open("domain", 'r') as f:
    cert=f.read()
r = requests.post("https://10.243.49.9/redfish/v1/CertificateService/Actions/CertificateService.ReplaceCertificate", verify=False, auth=("root", "0penBmc"), json={"CertificateUri":{"@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/NetworkProtocol/HTTPS/Certificates/1"}, "CertificateType": "PEM", "CertificateString": cert})

Checked the certificate actually got uploaded.

Everything is working as expected.  Fix the couple flow/error case problems, and this should be good to go.

Thanks for driving this home.

A POST is not supposed to be idempotent, however we treat this a replace (more like a PUT). So I think this should be a PUT.

All other Actions in bmcweb are using POST and specification states to use POST

ReplaceCertificate
This action is used to replace an existing certificate.
The following table shows the parameters for the action which are included in the POST body to the URI shown in the "target" property of the Action.

I also think that it should be POST as the actions should be defined as POST.

Other examples are
System Reset is under /redfish-core/lib/systems.hpp.
This is an action, but by definition POSTs are supposed to create something new, as opposed to replacing a resource.

Two use case of POST.

6.4.4.3 Create (POST)
The POST method is used to create a new resource. The POST request is submitted to the resource collection in which the new resource is to
belong.

6.4.4.5 Actions (POST)
The POST method is used to initiate operations on the object (such as Actions).
Services shall support the POST method for sending actions.
The POST operation may not be idempotent.

Here it is action so POST should be used.
This sounds good. Can you also let me know where this piece of information is from?
DSP0266

This is subtle, but relying on undefined behavior.

url.substr is going to return a std::string rvalue.
then calling c_str() on it, will return a pointer to said rvalue.
Before strtol is invoked, the rvalue will be destroyed, as it is no longer in scope, and there are no owning things looking at it.

If you declare your substr on the line above, all of the problems go away.

If i compare this function to how openssl parses these strings, I'm seeing some significant differences in how bad characters are parsed as well as multiple property values.

https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/7ed66e2634e6cfbb16a1ef975572e79a479217a8/apps/apps.c#L1607

I wonder, should we reading this into an openssl X509 subject, then reading the values out from there?  That way, we can make sure that we handle all the corner cases correctly.

What do you think?
responded below at line 544

To create X509 subject bmcweb need to have the certificate file, but as per design it does not have the certificate file(except during upload, it will not have when replacing or queriying for certificate details). Bmcweb queries phosphor-certificate-manager for certificate details.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-certificate-manager/blob/master/certificate.cpp#L294

phosphor-certificate-manager reads the certificate file using X509 subject and returns it as comma separated key value pairs as shown in above link.

Example
phosphor-certificate-manager returns the subject string as "C=US, ST=New York, L=Armonk, O=International"

as bmcweb is parsing the value returned by X509_get_subject_name from phosphor-certificate-manager the chances of bad characters, multiple values and e.t.c are not possible.

Please advise.
